subject: linear_algebra
title: Positive Definite Matrices
contentHtml:
A matrix is positive definite if it satisfies two conditions: first, all its eigenvalues are positive; second, it's symmetric.

This might seem like a narrow definition, but it has far-reaching implications in many fields. In particular, positive definite matrices play a crucial role in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Positive Definite Matrices
contentHtml:
A matrix is positive definite (PD) if it has only positive eigenvalues and all its minors are also PD.

This property is crucial in many applications, including machine learning, where PD matrices represent covariance or Gram matrices.
name: Eigenvalue characterization" },
intuition: Think of a PD matrix as a 'sum of squares' – all its eigenvalues are positive, indicating that the matrix represents a set of linearly independent directions with only positive projections.
realWorldApplications: In Gaussian mixture models, the covariance matrices of the components must be PD to ensure proper mixing.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse PD with symmetric or invertible – these properties are not equivalent.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Positive Definite Matrices
contentHtml:
A matrix is said to be positive definite (PD) if it satisfies a certain set of conditions that guarantee its eigenvalues are all positive.

This property is crucial in many applications, including machine learning and data analysis, as PD matrices can be used to model covariance structures or define probability distributions.

formula.latex: \[ A \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n} 	ext{ is positive definite if } x^T A x > 0 \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^n \]
formula.name: PD Matrix Condition

intuition: Think of a PD matrix as a 'stretched' identity matrix, where all eigenvalues are positive. This property ensures the matrix is invertible and has a unique inverse.
realWorldApplications: In Gaussian mixture models, PD matrices represent the covariance structure of each component.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse PD with positive semidefinite (PSD) matrices, which allow for zero eigenvalues.

subject: linear_algebra

problem.statementHtml: Given a positive definite matrix A, determine whether its square root exists and is also positive definite.
hints: Check if A has any zero eigenvalues.
Think about the relationship between the eigenvalues of A and those of its square root.
Recall that a matrix is positive definite if all its eigenvalues are positive.
problem.solutionHtml:
To show that the square root exists, we can use the fact that every symmetric positive definite matrix has only positive eigenvalues. Since A is positive definite, it must have only positive eigenvalues.

Now, let S be the matrix whose columns are the eigenvectors of A. Then, we can write A = SΛST, where Λ is a diagonal matrix containing the eigenvalues of A.

The square root of A is then given by S√ΛST. Since all eigenvalues in Λ are positive, so are those in √Λ. Therefore, the matrix S√ΛST is also positive definite.
problem.answerShort: The square root exists and is positive definite.

commonMistakes: Forgetting that a symmetric matrix must have only real eigenvalues.
Assuming the square root of A is unique, when it may not be.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Positive Definite Matrices
statementHtml: Given a symmetric matrix A, determine whether it is positive definite.
hints: Check if the matrix has any zero eigenvalues.
If the matrix has a negative eigenvalue, it cannot be positive definite.
Use the fact that all eigenvalues of a positive definite matrix are positive.
solutionHtml:
To prove this, we can use the following steps:

  1. Let A be a symmetric matrix.

  2. If A has any zero eigenvalues, it cannot be positive definite.

  3. Now assume that all eigenvalues of A are negative. Then there exists an eigenvector v with corresponding eigenvalue λ. We have:

    \[A\mathbf{v} = \lambda \mathbf{v}\]

  4. This implies that:

    \[\mathbf{v}^T A \mathbf{v} = \lambda \mathbf{v}^T \mathbf{v} = \lambda ||\mathbf{v}||^2 > 0,\]

    which is a contradiction since λ is negative.

  5. This shows that if all eigenvalues of A are negative, then it cannot be positive definite.

  6. Finally, we can conclude that:

    \[A\] is positive definite if and only if all its eigenvalues are positive.

    7. ",
answerShort: All eigenvalues of a positive definite matrix are positive." },
